Now she is seeking a loan to pay for her upcoming semester fees as she doesn't have enough money to do so.

loans.use: To pay for her upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Virgen De Copacabana Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “VIRGEN DEL CARMEN”; Este banco se ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Maribel, la socia continua con su negocio  de venta de salchipapas, pollipapas, la socia continua vendiendo de forma ambulatoria en la puerta de su casa, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia vende las salchipapas a todos sus clientes que le solicitan, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le trae satisfacciones personales y economicos, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de pollo, salchichas entre otros.
Los otros socios  se dedican a la venta de artesanía elaboración de refrigerios, venta de anticuchos, maestro constructor, brindando el servicio de taxi, agronomía.
Las socias que salen en la foto adjunta pidieron permiso para llegar tarde a la reunión por motivos de trabajo.
La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
These are the members of the “Virgen del Carmen” community bank, located in Cusco, in Cusco province, Cusco department.

Maribel is a member of this group. She continues with her business selling salchipapas (hotdog and fries) and pollipapas (chicken and fries), and still sells them from the door of her home. She is a responsible and hard-working person, who sells salchipapas to all her customers who ask for them. She has had her business for a long time, and it provides her with personal satisfaction as well as financial reward, this being her means of supporting her family.

Maribel is requesting the loan to buy chicken and hotdogs among other items. 

The other members make a living making snacks, selling kebabs, as a master builder, as a taxi driver, and in farming. The members in the photograph above had to apologise for arriving late to the meeting for work reasons. 

Maribel is grateful to those who contribute to her dream through Kiva and promises to make her loan repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy chicken and hot dogs among other things.

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Segundina works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending and vegetable vending. Segundina is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, spices, noodles, etc. for her general store business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Segundina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, spices, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Rosa Amanda

texts.es: Rosa  tiene 38 años de edad  originaria de la comunidad caña de castilla  tristemente dice que no pudo estudiar  por diferentes factores  de esa época  creció en un hogar bien unido con sus padres y hermanos , ella como hija mujer ayudaba a su mama en los cosas del hogar y sus hermanos con su padre en las tierras  sembrando frijoles y maíz, cuando cumplió  su mayoría de edad se casó y se fue de su casa pero siempre se quedó a vivir  en la misma comunidad  del matrimonio ha procreado 3 hijos con bastante esfuerzo dice que ella y su esposo adquirieron  hace 2 años   un sistema solar  para su hogar ahora ya hay que hacer cambio de la batería por eso quiere hacer  ella hacer tramite de crédito para así comprarla y hacer el cambio  de la batería.
texts.en:
Rosa is 38 years old, and is from the sugar cane community of Castilla. She says that sadly, she was unable to study due to various factors in the past. She grew up in a close family with her parents and siblings. As a young woman, she helped her mother with the household tasks and her brothers helped her father work the land, growing beans and corn. When she became an adult, she married and left home, but she stayed in the same village. She has three children with her husband. 

With a great deal of effort, she says that she and her husband bought a solar power system for their home two years ago. Now, the battery needs changing, which is why she wants a loan to buy and change the battery.

loans.use: to buy a battery for the solar power system she has installed in her home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Dulama

texts.en: Dulama is a 22-year-old lady who lives with her family that consists of five members in Irbid-Jordan. She is a university student majoring in English Language, and she is in her second year. She also works in the evenings at a mall, and she is planning to find a better job in her field of study after graduation. Now she is seeking a loan to pay for her upcoming semester fees as she doesn't have enough money to do so.

loans.use: To pay for her upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is 28 years old and married with two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buy and sell charcoal business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy sacks of charcoal to sell.

Daisy has borrowed and paid 1 loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy and sell charcoal business for 1 years and also earns an income from a general store.

Daisy aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy and sell charcoal

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is a maize farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Musa is excited about the opportunity to finally access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Musa can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from his farm, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Musa can reap up to 30 bags of maize per hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to expand my farmland, and I would like to provide a better education for my children: Shehu, Inusa and Ayuba. With this loan, Musa is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Gricelda Guadalupe

texts.es: Griselda tiene 40 años de edad, casada y madre de dos hijos ya independientes. Ella tiene deseos de salir adelante y es por eso que se encuentra en la última etapa de sus estudios: el curso de titulación. Su esposo es un pilar fundamental en su vida y en sus estudios ya que le ha apoyado significativamente. Solicita el crédito para pagar el título y lograr ser licenciada en Derecho. Dentro de sus planes futuros está seguirse especializando en las diversas ramas que presenta su carrera. Su meta próxima es finalizar el curso e incorporarse en la corte suprema de justicia. Su sueño próximo es llegar a ser juez.
texts.en:
Griselda is 40 years old, is married and a mother of two children who are already independent.  She wishes to get ahead and because of this she is beginning the last stage of her studies: her degree course. Her husband is an essential pillar in her life and has already supported her significantly in her studies.

She is requesting a loan to pay her tuition costs and become a Law graduate.  Her future plans include continuing to specialize in the different branches her studies offer.  Her next goal is to complete her studies and register with the Supreme Court.  Her ultimate dream is to become a judge.

loans.use: to pay tuition and fees

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a married woman; she has four children, all of whom attend school. Umazi owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Umazi operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other firewood operators in her business.
 
With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Sule

texts.en: Sule is a 25-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Sule, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Sule can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Sule is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least  35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Sule is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will be able to educate his young children: Alisa and  Ladi. Sule’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have access to professional jobs” he said.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Jamal A L- Waytat Group

texts.en:
Jamal Al- Waytat is a group which comprises of four members of women who live in Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 190,000 YER from AMB. Moluk is the leader of the group. She is a 39-year-old married woman, living with her spouse in their own house in Sana'a, Yemen.

Moluk is very active and dynamic woman and works as a house wife; her husband is the sole breadwinner of the family. Most people purchase many kinds of food materials for their houses in the holy month (Ramadhan) in order to support the needs of breaking fast. The people fast during the day of Ramadhan and they need delicious and good food for their breaking fast in the evening. For this reason, Moluk hopes to get an amount of money to prepare the house with all kinds of food materials in order to make delicious food for her family who fast during the days of Ramadhan. As a result, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase food materials to support all the needs of the house through Ramadan month.

Moluk looks forward to building the second floor of her house and renting the first one in order to improve the living condition of the family. She hopes to open a saving account in AMB.

loans.use: to purchase food materials to save all the needs of the house through Ramadhan month.

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en: Dauda is a 55-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Dauda is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Dauda is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to suppport and educate my children: Peter,Mary and Sarah. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Cecil

texts.en:
Cecil works hard to support her family. Cecil is single and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 5000 loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

Cecil has been in this business for 8 years now.

In the future, Cecil would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita is 39 years old and married with four children, two of whom in school.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buy and sell charcoal business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5000 loan through NWTF to buy sacks of charcoal to sell in her business.

Elenita has borrowed and paid 1 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy and sell charcoal business for 1 years and also earns an income from a general store.

Elenita aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to sell in her business

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie works hard to support her family. Rosalie is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 5000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.

Rosalie has been in this business for 4 years now.

In the future, Rosalie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his upcoming semester fees

loans.name: Anoud

texts.en: Anoud is a 19-year-old single lady living in Irbid-Jordan with her family. She is a university student majoring in Social Science, and she is in her third year. She is seeking to get her Bachelors’ so that she will be able to get her Masters’ in the future and improve her knowledge in addition to getting a good job in her study field to support her family financially. She currently needs a loan to pay for her upcoming semester fees as she doesn't have enough money to do so.

loans.use: to cover her upcoming university tuition

loans.name: Yohanna Mani

As a Babban Gona member, Yohanna Mani, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yohanna Mani can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Yohanna Mani is ambitious and is aiming to reap 56 bags per hectare this season due to the yield enhancing inputs that he will access with this loan. When asked how he plans to spend the income that he makes from selling his maize at the end of the season, Yohanna Mani said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children. Ultimately,  I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Virgelyn

texts.en:
Virgelyn is 33 years old and married with two children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Virgelyn is borrowing 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy more pigs to sell.

Virgelyn has been raising pigs for five years and also earns additional income from running a general store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more pigs to sell

loans.name: Kasichana

texts.en:
Kasichana is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Haruna Bala

As a Babban Gona member, Haruna Bala is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Haruna Bala can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Haruna Bala is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Yahuza,Suleman, and Mika. My overall goal is to ensure my children have access to professional jobs." With this loan, Haruna is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Ishaya Tura

texts.en: Ishaya Tura is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako. As a Babban Gona member, Ishaya Tura, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaya Tura can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Ishaya Tura is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ishaya Tura said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Nuhu, Inusa and Danlami, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children have access to professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es: Pedro  es habitante de la comunidad caña de castilla  tiene 43 años no pudo continuar  la  escuela porque en ese entonces era  periodo de guerra  así que era un poco peligroso andar en las carreteras solo. Por lo  que solo estudio  hasta segundo grado de primaria, su padre le enseño a trabajar las tierras  para que así el pudiera defenderse en la vida , hace 11 años  se casó y tiene una hija de ese matrimonio  la niña tiene 3 años de edad su esposa es ama de casa y el cultiva granos básicos y hortalizas ,actualmente en su vivienda tiene instalado un sistema solar sin embargo ya necesita hacer cambio de la batería es por eso que solicita el préstamo para así comprarla y su sistema siga funcionando perfectamente .
texts.en: Pedro is 43 years old and lives in Caña de Castilla. He had to stop going to school after finishing the second grade because a war made it rather dangerous for him to walk the streets alone. Pedro's father taught him to work the land so that he could earn a living and take are of himself. Pedro got married 11 years ago, and is now the father of a three-year-old daughter. Pedro's wife takes care of their daughter and their home while he works on their farm, where he grows staple grains and vegetables. The couple's home has a solar power system, which needs a new battery.  Pedro is therefore applying for a loan so that he can purchase the battery and keep the solar power system operating smoothly.

loans.use: to purchase a battery for his solar power system.

loans.name: Yahaya Gambo

texts.en: Yahaya Gambo remembers feeling depressed  as a result of a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Yahaya Gambo, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yahaya Gambo is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season due to the high-quality inputs that he will access with this loan. When asked about the future, he said: “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Talatu

texts.en: Talatu is a Babban Gona farmer from Dogon Fako. Talatu is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Talatu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Talatu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Talatu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, she will finally be able to access the required yield-enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Talatu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, she will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked, she said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.” With this loan, Talatu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Truphena

texts.en:
Wonderful Kiva Lenders! Meet Truphena, 47 years of age, a very hardworking woman, enterprising and a go-getter. She hails from the Nyamira area of Kenya, an area referred to as a “banana region.“ This is because all farmers grow bananas and their staple food is “matoke,” a mouthwatering delicacy prepared from bananas. Truphena has her secondary education, which she could not continue past because her parents could not support her, but that never killed the spirit in her to succeed in life and have a good life.

She started farming and has been doing it for the past 20 years. Through mixed farming (that is, crop and animal farming), she has been able to earn a decent income and also provide for her family.

Dairy farming is close to Truphena's heart and she really enjoys doing dairy farming with a lot of passion, but one challenge she is facing is lack of a proper dairy unit, so that is why she is kindly seeking funds to build a dairy unit. Through the loan, her cows will never be sick because they will have a good place to stay, and also bad weather conditions will never affect the cows. The dairy unit will boost milk production because when cows are more relaxed, they produce a lot of milk and that means improved income.

Truphena is very honest with finances and she projects that through saved profits, she will be able to buy another quality dairy cow within a year. Truphena notes down all the profits she makes and takes keen interest in all the income she gets. Earlier costs that were being incurred in buying medicine will not be there, hence she will have more income and assure her family a brighter future. Through your loan, Truphena will be able to be economically empowered and will have improved living conditions.

loans.use: to build a dairy unit

loans.name: Kumbo

texts.en:
Kumbo is a married woman. She has 4 children, all of whom attend school. Together with her husband, they live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She has operated a fresh water selling business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, especially during the rainy season the business is low. 

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase gallons for her business. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase gallons for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cement

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase grocery items

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is married and has five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Chizi runs a business making and selling dumplings and flat bread. She sells from her home to her neighbours and passers-by. Seasonality is the major challenge she faces in her business. 

With this 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) loan, she wants to buy wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Honest Group Ishaka

texts.en:
Dauda is a professional tailor based in Ishaka town, located in Bushenyi district in Uganda. He is a member of Honest Group, age 62 years, and has been in this business since he was a teenager. 

He started borrowing from UGAFODE Microfinance in the year 2009, with the amount of 200,000 ugsh and has been graduating since then up to this time, when he is requesting a loan through the group. (600,000 shillings only). He is married, and a father of 12; 4 of these are in school and 8 of them are now out of school and doing their own businesses. He looks after a total of four orphans who lost their both parents. 

He started his business in the year 1972, and works 10 hours on a normal working day. But when he has orders, he works for 14 hours to meet the deadlines of his clients, who are mostly Ishaka town people. 

He begun this business to build his own life, and have a better life for his family and himself. He is taking this loan to buy more cloth materials since his clients had ordered kinyankole suits. He hopes to build a clothing store where he wants to train more young people in the tailoring business, like he is doing now using the small space that he has. He is challenged by creditors and debtors. 

He thanks UGAFODE Microfinance so much for supporting him in his business, the rising of his children in terms of school fees, and his family at large.

loans.use: To buy cloth for sewing

texts.en:
Maryamu Tasalla is a 40-year-old farmer from Dogon Fako.  As a Babban Gona member, Maryamu Tasalla, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Maryamu Tasalla can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. Maryamu Tasalla is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children: Zakaria and Musa. Maryamu Tasalla’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children have access to professional jobs”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: José Ramón

texts.es:
José tiene 36 años de edad, estudió hasta 6ª grado, está acompañado y tiene 3 hijas entre 9 y 14 años de edad, su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos y al comercio de mariscos.

José se dedica a la pesca artesanal, él conoce muy bien al actividad que realiza ya que desde pequeño ha ejercido dichas labores, esto lo aprendió de su padre y amigos que fueron quienes le ayudaron para que conociera dicha actividad y también realiza producción de granos básicos.

Él necesita el crédito para comprar redes que utiliza para  pescar ya que actualmente las que tiene se encuentran bastante deterioradas y necesita mejorar su equipo de pesca, además invertirá para comprar fertilizantes para la siembra de maíz.

Él sueña con que su familia tenga un mejor lugar para vivir y seguir trabajando duro para lograr sus objetivos.
texts.en:
José, 36, studied up to sixth grade.  He's married and has three daughters between the ages of 9 and 14.  His wife takes care of the home and sells shrimp.

José earns a living in artisanal fishing.  He knows his job very well because he has done it since he was young.  He learned it from his father and friends, who helped him become familiar with the job.  He also grows basic grains.

He needs the loan to buy fishing nets because the ones he has now are very worn out and he needs to improve his fishing equipment.  He'll also invest in buying fertilizer to grow corn.

He dreams of his family having a better place to live and of continuing to work hard to achieve his goals.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
This is 29-year-old Irene from Chipinge, a town in south-eastern Zimbabwe. She is single with two children, and one is attending school. She also cares for two other dependents.

Irene runs a printing business doing photocopying and typing services. The business has been in operation for 5 years. She says the main challenge being faced is a lack of working capital.

Irene has requested a loan of $800 to purchase typing materials. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the family's general welfare. In the future, Irene plans to have a printing company.

loans.use: to pay for bond paper and ink cartridges

loans.name: Sanita

texts.en:
Sanita is a married woman with one child. She lives in her own home, which has electricity and running water.

She has operated a small shop for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. Seasonality is the major challenge she faces in her business. 

With this loan, she wants to buy stocks of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of sugar, rice and flour

loans.name: Kanga

texts.en:
Kanga is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Glenda Del Rocio

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Cdla. Los Almendros se reúne cada 15 días en el barrio Los Almendros en la ciudad de Manta,  ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año y por ser una ciudad con una belleza sin igual con muchos atractivos turísticos.
En este lugar vive la señora Glenda, tiene 41 años de edad,  está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos, uno mayor de edad y otro de 13 años que estudia en colegio. Su esposo es conserje en una institución privada.
Doña Glenda es una mujer que siempre le ha gustado ganar lo suyo para salir adelante ella y sus hijos, ella  se dedica a la venta de productos de Leudine y Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, realiza sus recorridos  todos los días ya que así se entretiene visitando sus clientes aunque también vende en su casa, deja a crédito y cobra  cada semana. Lleva más de 10 años con este negocio.
Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas y cosméticos. Lleva más de 10 años en el Grupo De Crédito le gusta por la ayuda de los créditos. Sus sueños son seguir adelante y tener buena salud.
texts.en:
The Credit Group Cdla. Los Almendros meets every fortnight in the Los Almendros neighbourhood of Manta city. Manta is known for its beautiful beaches, which are very popular with visitors throughout the year, and for being a city of unrivalled beauty with many tourist attractions.

Glenda lives here. She is 41 years old, married and she and her husband have two children. One is now grown-up and the other is 13 years old and in school. Her husband is the caretaker in a private institution.

Glenda is a woman who has always liked to earn her own money. To enable herself and her children to get ahead, she sells products from Leudine and Yanbal (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and accessories for women). She sells door to door. She does her rounds every day, as she enjoys visiting customers, but she also sells from home and allows credit sales and purchase by weekly payment. She has been in this business for more than 10 years.

This loan is to buy perfumes, creams and cosmetics. She has been with the Credit Group for over 10 years. She likes it because of the help which loans give her. Her dreams are to keep moving forwards and to have good health.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, creams and cosmetics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Rijoya

texts.en: Rijoya is a maize farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Rijoya is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Rijoya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Rijoya is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Obida,Faresa and Obadiya. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: María Virmania

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Cdla. Los Almendros se reúne cada 15 días en el barrio Los Almendros en la ciudad de Manta,  ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año y por ser una ciudad con una belleza sin igual con muchos atractivos turísticos.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 34 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 10, 7 y 3 años, los dos mayores estudian en escuela. El marido es militar. 
Doña María con la finalidad de contar con sus propios ingresos se dedica a la venta de ropa, zapatos, sabanas, carteras, entre otras cosas, ella sale todos los días en las mañanas aprovechando que sus hijos están en sus escuelas para salir con más comodidad ya que solo tiene que llevar al más pequeño, aunque también vende en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes más conocidos, ella deja sus productos a crédito y  cobra por semana o quincenas de acuerdo a como lo deseen sus clientes, lleva más de 6 años  en esta actividad que le sirve para salir adelante. 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar ropa, carteras, zapatos, entre otras cosas que vende. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos financia su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The loan group Ciudadela Los Almendros meets every two weeks in the Los Almendros neighborhood in the city of Manta, a city known for its beautiful beaches, which are much visited in every season of the year, and for being a city of unequaled beauty with many tourist attractions.

Señora Maria lives here. She is 34 years old. She is married and from this relationship has three children, ages 10, 7, and 3; the older two are in school. Her husband is in the military.

With the goal of having her own income, Doña Maria sells clothing, shoes, sheets, and handbags, among other items. She goes out every day in the morning, taking advantage of the time that her children are in school to go out more comfortably, since she only has to bring the littlest one, although she also sells in her house, where the customers she knows best come. She leaves her products on credit and collects every week or two weeks, according to what her customers want. She has been in this business for more than six years, and it is helping her to get ahead.

She is going to use this loan to buy clothing, handbags, and shoes, among other items that she sells. She has been in the loan group since its beginning, and she likes it because she finances her business with the loans. Her dreams are to give the best to her children.

loans.use: to buy clothing, handbags, shoes, etc. to sell

loans.name: Fulmala

texts.en:
Fulmala is an enterprising woman of 25 years from the small village Gosairhat in the district of Jalpaiguri. She is married and a mother of one young son, who is a student of grade 1. She and her husband, Sanatan, attended school till grade 6 and 8, and could not continue study for the inadequate economic resources of their family. Her husband works as a laborer in a local motor garage.

Due to inconsistent income of her husband, Fulmala has been practicing cattle farming for the last few years to give sustenance to her family through dairy. She finds dairy farming enjoyable and profitable. She has a dairy cow and a goat on her farm. She supplies milk from door to door to her neighbors. In order to increase her business, she needs to purchase one more dairy cow. But the biggest problem she faces is limited funds.

Fulmala  is seeking a loan to buy a dairy cow. It will produce enough milk to enable her to supply more and satisfy her customers, thus earning more. So, she has taken a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS.

She hopes to purchase more cows in the future to enlarge her business. Her goals are to construct a better and decent house and give higher education to their son.

 She gives her heartiest thanks to her lenders, BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow for her existing milk selling business.

loans.name: Jayanti

texts.en:
Jayanti is an enthusiastic and energetic woman, 27 years old, and the mother of two sons. She is a housewife and lives accompanied by her life partner. She attended school up to class V (grade 5), whereas her husband, Amal, studied up to seventh standard. Both their sons are receiving education. They are in class IV (grade 4), and class II (grade 2). They live in their own kachha house (mud, bamboo and straw-made) in the small village of Tekatuli in the district of Jalpaiguri.

Jayanti’s husband is a cycle-van puller but the van is not his own; it is rented from a local owner. Her husband’s income is too low to run a family of four members, as life is getting more expensive over time.

Jayanti heard about BJS (Kiva’s partner) and applied for a loan to buy a cycle-van for her husband to carry people and loads from one place to another. They hope that their earnings will be more from this, as they will not have to pay any rent.

Her future dreams are to offer their children a better education and to enjoy a better quality of life. 

Her full thanks go to both BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a cycle-van for her husband.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is a 45-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Amina, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Amina can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Amina is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, she will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Amina is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children: Gadafi  and Biliya. Amina’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Eli

texts.en: Eli is a 35-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Eli is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Eli can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Eli is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Tabita,Suzana, and Labon. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Nuhu

texts.en:
Nuhu is a Babban Gona farmer from Ung/Tsirya. Nuhu expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Nuhu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Nuhu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Nuhu can reap up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. By doing so, Nuhu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Nuhu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Enma Eloisa

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Cdla. Los Almendros se reúne cada 15 días en el barrio Los Almendros en la ciudad de Manta,  ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año y por ser una ciudad con una belleza sin igual con muchos atractivos turísticos.
En este lugar vive la señora Enma, tiene 34 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 12, 9 y 7 años que estudian en colegio y escuela. El marido es sastre y comerciante.
Doña Enma junto al esposo tienen un taller de costura en su casa,  ellos confeccionan ropa de todo tipo ya sea de damas o caballeros, además de confeccionar ropa también se dedican al comercio, ciertos días de la semana instalan un local en el mercado de Tarqui en el cual venden ropa interior, los fines de semana se desplazan a otras ciudades en los días de feria a vender sus productos ya que es cuando más personas llegan a estos lugares y cuando mas compran, tienen más de 10 años con su taller el cual les permite salir adelante.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar materiales de costura y ropa interior. Lleva 4 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le son de mucha ayuda. Sus sueños son tener un local para vende su mercadería.
texts.en:
The Credit Group Cdla. Los Almendros meets every fortnight in the Los Almendros neighbourhood of Manta city. Manta is known for its beautiful beaches, which are very popular with visitors throughout the year, and for being a city of unrivalled beauty with many tourist attractions.

Enma lives here. She is 34 years old, married and she and her husband have three children who are 12, 9 and 7 years old and in primary and secondary school. Her husband is a tailor and shopkeeper.

Enma and her husband have a sewing workshop at home. They make clothes of all kinds, for either ladies or gentlemen. Besides making clothes, they also trade: on certain days of the week they set up a stall in Tarqui market from which they sell underwear. At weekends, they travel to other cities on market days to sell their products because that is when most people go to these places and when they buy more. They have had their workshop for more than 10 years and it allows them to get by.

This loan is going to be used to purchase sewing materials and underwear. Enma has been with the Credit Group for over 4 years and she likes it because the loans are a great help to her. Her dream is to have a premises from which to sell her merchandise.

loans.use: to buy sewing supplies and underwear.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 57-year-old farmer from Ung/Tsirya.  As a Babban Gona member, John is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, John can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, John can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. John is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford a better education for his children:  Dauda, Janet  and Jonathan. John’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Ishaya

texts.en:
Ishaya is a 37-year-old farmer from Ung/Tsirya.  As a Babban Gona member, Ishaya is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Ishaya can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. Ishaya is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children:  Kefas, Adamu and Blessen. Ishaya’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: Salamatu is a 35-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Salamatu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Salamatu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Salamatu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give her access to high quality, unadulterated inputs.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Ezekiel, Danlami, and Na'ama. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Adolfo Jose

texts.es: Adolfo ha vivido toda su vida en la comunidad   de caña de castilla  con sacrificio dice que en sus tiempos logro terminar la escuela primaria ya que para en ese entonces estaba la guerra civil así que a jóvenes de la edad de 13 años en adelante los reclutaban para el servicio militar y le toco andar huyendo por mucho tiempo, una vez que eso paso el regreso a casa de sus padres se puso a trabajar en unas manzanas de tierra que tenía su papa y así poco a poco él fue construyendo su patrimonio se caso  vive en su vivienda con su esposa, hijos y nietos  dice en su familia se practica la unión familiar el respeto y a luchar día a día  por llevar el pan de cada día al hogar , en su vivienda ya cuentan con energía eléctrica ya que tiene instalado un sistema solar  sin embargo ahora quiere aplicar a un préstamo para hacer el cambio  de la batería y regulador del sistema para que este siempre le siga funcionando al 100%.
texts.en: Adolfo has lived all his life in the community of Caña de Castilla. He says that in his day, he managed to finish primary school with sacrifice, since by that time the civil war was taking place, so the youths from the age of 13 and up were conscripted for military service, and he had to flee for a long time. Once this passed, he returned to his parents' house. He began to work on some plots of land that his father had, and thus little by little he was building his legacy. He married, and he lives in his house with his wife, children, and grandchildren. He says that in his family they believe in family unity, respect, and striving every day to bring the daily bread to the household. In his home they have electrical energy, since he has installed a solar power system. Nevertheless, he now wants to apply for a loan to make a change in the battery and regulator for the system, so that it will always continue functioning for him at 100%.

loans.use: to buy the components that he needs to change his solar energy system.

loans.name: Sumati

texts.en:
Sumati a very hardworking, honest woman of Maynaguri. She is a mother of two lovely and adorable sons whom she really cherishes, and she will do anything in her power to fully provide for them.  She is 35 years old and was deprived of education due to her parents' poverty, so she can sign her name only. Her husband, Gobinda, who is 50 years old and has a secondary education, works as an electrician. Her sons are students of grades 4 and 6. They live in a small village Khagrabari in Jalpaiguri district.

Sumati's husband has no fixed income, so it is very difficult to run the family. For getting an extra income Sumati has been farming for the last few years and through these years she has been making tremendous strides in profits. Sumati’s primary source of income is milk selling, and through this she has managed to earn a decent and honest income.

Sumati is planning to expand her business of selling milk to her neighbors and around the market. The main challenge she is facing is the inability to access funds. That is why she is kindly requesting a loan from BJS (Kiva's partner) to buy a dairy cow. Through the loan, Sumati will be able to acquire more income and she will be able to secure her children's future and also improve her living conditions.

Sumati's plan is not only to sell her milk to the nearby market, but to be able to sell to other markets and hence increase her income and improve her living standards. She wants to provide better education to her sons so that they will become successful.

She is very much grateful to her lenders Kiva and BJS.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow for her milk supply business.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is  married and has been blessed with seven children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past six months, she has operated a vegetable kiosk business, selling green vegetables, tomatoes and potatoes. She sells primarily to local neighbours. Margret dreams of expanding and establishing a shop in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma appreciates the previous loan that helped her expand her business.

 She sells fruits and green vegetables. She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. Fatuma is requesting a loan to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Hauwa

texts.en: Hauwa is a 25-year-old farmer from Galadima. As a Babban Gona member, Hauwa, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hauwa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Hauwa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Hauwa said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs." With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: José Francisco

texts.es:
José tiene 34 años de edad, no tiene ningún nivel académico, vive junto a sus tres hijos, dos de ellos se  encuentran estudiando en preparatoria, también vive con su compañera de vida que se dedica a los oficios domésticos.


José se dedica a la pesca artesanal, dichas labores las aprendió de su padre y amigos además se dedica a la producción de granos básicos.

Él necesita el crédito para comprar redes que utilizará para la pesca ya que actualmente las que posee se encuentran deterioradas, además comprará fertilizantes para la compra de maíz.

Él sueña con seguir trabajando en la pesca ya que es lo que a él le gusta.
texts.en: José is 34 years old and did not attend school. He lives with his three children. Two of them are studying in High school. He also lives with his life companion who does domestic work.  José works doing small scale fishing, work that he learned from his father and friends. He also grows basic grains. He needs a loan to buy nets that he will use for fishing as the ones he has are in poor condition. He will also buy fertilizer to grow corn. His dream is to continue to work fishing as this is what he enjoys.

loans.use: to buy nets for fishing and fertilizer to grow corn.

loans.name: Basanti

texts.en:
Basanti is a very energetic and active young entrepreneur who hails from Maynaguri. She is a mother of two children (one son and one daughter). Her children attend school and are in grade 6 and grade 3. They live in a small village, Tekatuli, in Jalpaiguri district. Basanti and her husband are illiterate and can sign their names only.

Basanti's husband runs a small business that makes and sells bamboo products in their village. In villages, small businesses are intricately linked to local economic upheavals. This also means that his income, though seemingly substantial, is irregular and uncertain. These conditions have forced Basanti to explore alternatives that would provide a regular source of income. After some exploratory study she has decided on the manufacture and selling of incense sticks as a viable business venture. Now her business is the main source of income for the family.

In order to generate more income to cope with the price rise in essential commodities, she wants to make more incense to get more profit. So she applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva's partner) to purchase raw materials such as bamboo sticks, perfume, sandalwood powder, etc. She hopes this loan will help her to increase her profit so that she can lead a decent lifestyle and provide better education to her children. She dreams to get ahead with this business.

She is grateful to her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her incense making business.

loans.name: Amner

texts.es:
Amner tiene 27 años de edad, estudió hasta 6ª grado, vive junto a sus dos hijos y su pareja que se dedica a los oficios domésticos.

Amner se dedica a la pesca artesanal, lo aprendió por un tío suyo que también se dedicaba a lo mismo, Amner conoce muy bien esta actividad la cual se ha convertido en el sustento diario para él y su familia. 

Él necesita este crédito para comprar redes que utiliza para la pesca porque las que posee actualmente están bastante deterioradas. 

Amner sueña con que su familia viva en un lugar estable y que nunca les falte nada.
texts.en: Amner is 27 years old and studied up to Grade 6. He lives with his two children and his spouse. She does domestic work. Amner works at small scale fishing which he learned from an uncle who does the same thing. Amner knows this business well which he has converted into the daily sustenance for his family. He needs this loan to buy nets that he will use for fishing as the ones he has are in poor condition. Amner dreams of his family living in a stable place and lacking nothing.

loans.use: to buy nets for fishing.

loans.name: Begam

texts.en:
Begam is a 30-year-old housewife. She is from Maynaguri. She has attended school up to eighth grade and wanted to carry on, but did not have the support of her parents as they were really badly off economically. She grew up and married Tariful. Her husband is a farmer and she is a housewife, and they have three children (one son and two daughters). Two of the children go to school and one is too small for school.

The full family is dependent on her husband's agribusiness financially. He has worked in agriculture since he was very young. He works all day long on his farmland and grows vegetables and sells them in the local market to earn for the family.

Now Begam wants to expand her agribusiness to be able to effectively meet the growing needs of her family. She and her husband have decided to cultivate jute, which is a much demanded crop in their locality. A loan will enable her to buy agricultural inputs like seeds, fertilizers and chemicals for plants and so she is asking for a loan for that purpose from BJS (Kiva's partner).
 
She is very happy with this loan, which she knows can change their income level and standard of living. Her goals are to admit her children to renowned schools for better education.

Her full thanks go to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural inputs for farming jute.

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a maize farmer from Kiyawa.  As a Babban Gona member, Maryamu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Maryamu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Maryamu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked, Maryamu said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Eli, Danjuma and Alheri, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs." With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha is a 25-year-old farmer from Galadima. As a Babban Gona member, Aisha, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Aisha can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Aisha is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season due to the yield-enhancing inputs that she will access with this loan. When asked how she plans to use the money she will make from selling her produce, Aisha said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children, Friday and Saratu. Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Martha Beatriz

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Cdla. Los Almendros se reúne cada 15 días en el barrio Los Almendros en la ciudad de Manta,  ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año y por ser una ciudad con una belleza sin igual con muchos atractivos turísticos.
En este lugar vive la señora Martha, tiene 37 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cinco  hijos de 19, 17, 14  y gemelas de 12 años,  los menores estudian en colegio. El marido trabaja en una fabrica local.
Doña Martha es un ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos y con esto ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la venta de productos l´eudine (productos de belleza y cosméticos), además de productos naturales, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, realiza sus recorridos  cuatro días a la semana,  deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Tiene más de 3  años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual  paga los estudios de a sus hijos que para ella son los más importante.
Este crédito es para comprar  cremas, cosméticos y productos naturales. Lleva más de 4 años en el Grupo De Crédito le gusta porque con los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The "Cdla. Los Almendros" communal bank meets every fortnight in the Los Almendros neighborhood of the city of Manta. This city is famous for it's beautiful beaches that are visited year round and as a city with unequaled beauty that has many tourist attractions.

Marta lives in this city. She is 37 years old and is in a common-law relationship. She has five children aged 19, 17, 14 and 12 year old twins. The youngest study in school. Her husband works in a local factory.

Martha is a housewife who in order to make her own income and to help her husband with the household expenses works selling L'Eudine products (beauty products and cosmetics) and natural products. She sells door to door, making her rounds four times per week. She leaves her product on credit and collects once a week. She has been doing this business for more than 3 years so she can pay for her children's studies, which is the most important thing for her.

The loan is to buy creams, cosmetics and natural products. She has been a member of the communal bank for more than 4 years and she likes it as she used it to start her business. Her dream is to provide the best for her children.

loans.use: to buy creams, cosmetics and natural products.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman. She has no children. She has operated a fresh water selling business for the past ten years, selling from home to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of seasonality especially during the rainy season when business is low. 

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase a water tank and install a water tap for her business. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank and install a water tap for her business

loans.name: Bernarda Nicolaza

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Cdla. Los Almendros se reúne cada 15 días en el barrio Los Almendros en la ciudad de Manta,  ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año y por ser una ciudad con una belleza sin igual con muchos atractivos turísticos.
En este lugar vive la señora Bernarda, tiene 47 años de edad, está divorciada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Ella hace muchos años atrás aprendió corte y confección en una academia de la localidad.
Doña Bernarda con la finalidad de obtener sus propios ingresos y aprovechando sus conocimientos en corte y confección puso en su casa un pequeño taller de costura, allí ella se dedica a confeccionar todo tipo de ropa, también se dedica al comercio, tiene un pequeño local en el mercado de Tarqui lugar en el cual vende ropa que ella misma confecciona y zapatos. Trabaja todos los días, lleva más de 20 años con su taller de costura el cual le sirvió para sacar adelante a sus hijos y ahora le permiten salir adelante a ella.
Este nuevo crédito lo va utilizar en comprar ropa, zapatillas, telas y otros materiales de costura. Lleva 4 ciclos en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos ella sale adelante. Sus sueños son seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The Ciudadela Los Almendros [Almond Tree Citadel] Credit Group meets twice a month in the Los Almendros section of the city of Manta. This area is known for its unmatched beauty, many tourist attractions, and the spectacular coastline that draws crowds of beach-lovers throughout the year.   

This is where Señora Bernarda lives. She is a 47-year-old seamstress, divorced, and the mother of two adult children who live on their own. Señora Bernarda learned dressmaking and tailoring over 20 years ago in a local academy. She then used this training to set up a small dressmaking workshop in her home, where she makes all kinds of clothing. She also has a small shop in the market in Tarqui, where she sells her clothes as well as shoes. Señora Bernarda has worked every day for many years, earning the income that allowed her to support herself and her children.  

Señora Bernarda will use the funds from this loan to purchase clothing, shoes, fabric, and other dressmaking materials. She has been through four loan cycles with the Almond Tree Citadel Group, and has been pleased that these loans have allowed her to prosper. She hopes to continue operating her business successfully.

loans.use: to purchase clothing, shoes, fabric, and other dressmaking materials.

loans.name: Al- Hendwan Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Hendwan. It consists of four women. They all live in traditional and simple families in the capital city of Sana'a, Yemen. They know one another through friendship and neighborhood connections. They applied for a loan of 160,000 YER from AMB. 

Fatima is a 35-year-old married woman and a mother of two children. She is the leader of the group. Fatima lives with her family in their own house. She is an uneducated woman and she works as a housewife. She is very dynamic and vigorous. Over time her husband was able to accumulate good amount of money and purchase a piece of land. Fatima supported him with a lot of  her  own money. Her husband is the sole breadwinner of the family and his income is not enough to cover all the expenses of the household. 

Fatima  and her husband are building their own house on that land they bought, but it is still very small and not yet completed. As a result, Fatima is requesting a loan of 40,000 YER from AMB. She will use the loan to purchase construction materials as cement and bricks in order to build other rooms to make the house more comfortable and large.

Fatima's dream in the future is building another floor and renovating it.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials such as cement and bricks  to build other rooms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy enough cartons of fish to sell.

loans.name: Metala

texts.en: Metala is a 28-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Metala is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Metala can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Metala is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give him access to high quality inputs that will boost his yield.  When asked how he plans to spend his expected income at the end of the season, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice remembers not being able to feed her family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Alice, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Alice  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Alice. With this loan, Alice is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay his semester fees and continue his studies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock his mini-market with new products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy enough goods such as used clothes to sell.

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.es:
María tiene 22 años de edad, no pudo culminar sus estudios de bachillerato, está felizmente acompañada y su pareja se dedica a la agricultura, tiene 3 hijos los cuales están pequeños y solo el mayor está yendo a kínder.


María se dedica a los cuidos del hogar y de sus hijos, pero también se dedica a alimentar unos cerdos que tienen en el patio de su casa, ya tiene 2 años dedicándose al destazo de cerdos para vender la carne, este es un negocio familiar que viene de generación en generación, ellos compran los cerdos ya grandes, los destazan y luego venden sus productos, en esta actividad participa su esposo y su madre que es vecina de ellos.

El préstamo lo necesitan para comprar más cerdos y así ir ampliando poco a poco el negocio.

Ella sueña con mejorar su casa y tener toda una granja de cerdos con lo cual pueda obtener buenos ingresos económicos para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Maria, 22, did not finish school. She is happily living with her partner who works in agriculture. She has three small children with only the eldest going to kindergarten.

Maria looks after the home and her children but she also takes care of some pigs that they have in the backyard and has been selling this pig meat for two years. This is a family business that has been passed down from generation to generation; they buy the pigs already grown, butcher them and then sell the meat. Her partner and her mother, who lives nearby, also help with this.

She needs this loan to buy more pigs and then slowly expand the business.

Her dream is to improve her home and have a whole pig farm with which she can get a good and stable income to get by in life.

loans.use: to buy more pigs and then slowly expand the business.

loans.name: Flora

texts.es:
Flora tiene 44 años de edad, estudió hasta bachillerato, está acompañada y su pareja se dedica a la agricultura y también es sastre, tiene 3 hijos, de los cuales dos todavía van a la escuela.

Flora se dedica a la elaboración de tortillas,  ya tiene 8 años dedicándose a esta labor, inició con poco cuando un tío le obsequió una cocina vieja que él tenía, ahora ya sabe bien el oficio y muele aproximadamente un quintal de maíz diario, la tortillería se encuentra en su casa y su hija mayor se involucra en este trabajo.

Ella necesita el crédito para comprar maíz para la elaboración de tortillas, y les urge pues el precio está cada día más caro debido a la gran sequía que hubo en el país, donde solo unos pocos lograron producir.

Ella sueña con ampliar el negocio y ver que sus hijos se superen en la vida y formen su propio hogar.
texts.en: Flora is 44 years old and completed her secondary school studies. She is married and her partner works in agriculture and also is a tailor. She has 3 children. all of whom go to school. Flora has been making makes tortillas for 8 years. She started small when an uncle gave her an old stove that he had. She now knows the business well and grinds about a quintal of corn daily. The tortilla shop is located in her house and her oldest daughter is involved in the work. She needs the loan to buy corn to make her tortillas. It is urgent as the price of corn is rising every due to the drought in the country where only a few have manged to produce. She dreams of expanding her business and see her children excel in life and make their own families.

loans.use: to buy corn to make tortillas.

loans.name: Mozahem Group

texts.en:
This group is called Mozahem. It comprises three women and one man from Taiz city, Yemen. They are requesting a loan of 260,000 YER from AMB.

Arwa is the leader of the group. She is 35 years old, a  married woman living with her spouse in their own house in a Taiz village. Arwa works as a housewife and she is a very dynamic and active woman. Their house needs renovation from the inside. Most of rooms are not renovated, in addition to the kitchen and the bathroom. This affects Arwa negatively and she feels ashamed, especially if any guests or visitors come to her house. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 80,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase cement to renovate the house from the inside.

Arwa looks forward to improving the living standards of her family. She plans to build a large yard for her house.

loans.use: to purchase cement to renovate the house from the inside.

loans.name: Na'omi

texts.en:
Na'omi is a 40-year-old farmer from Barangwaje.  As a Babban Gona member, Na'omi is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Na'omi can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Na'omi can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Zakariya, Bilya and  Hannatu. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Dinatu

texts.en:
Dinatu is a 25-year-old farmer from Barangulaje.  As a Babban Gona member, Dinatu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Dinatu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Dinatu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Ezra, Ayuba, and  Rijoya. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Sop Mame Babacar 3" Beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Sop Mame Babacar 3 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes commerçantes et transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. La responsable du groupe, madame Daba, mariée et mère de famille, évolue dans la transformation et la commercialisation de poissons séchés et fumés où elle a acquis une expérience de plus de 10 ans. Grâce à ce crédit, elle compte acheter deux charrettes de poisson pour le transformer en poisson fumé et en poisson séché destiné à la commercialisation. Daba n’a pas de charges sinon ses propres besoins et ceux de ses enfants.
 Elle désire faire du commerce de produits cosmétiques et ouvrir pour sa fille un salon de coiffure.
texts.en:
The Beug Manal Sa Bop is a subgroup of the Sop Mame Babacar 3 borrowers' group, which is a network of of female entrepreneurs who process fish products for sale. This group is composed off five women who have been in business for many years and have joined forces in order to benefit from financial support allowing them to strengthen their businesses. The group's leader, Mrs. Daba, is married and has children. She process and sells dried and smoked fish, having over 10 years of experience in this line of work. Thanks to this loan, she plans to buy two cartloads of fish in order to prepare smoked and dried fish for resale. Daba has no financial obligations other than providing for her own needs and those of her children.
She would also like to start a business selling cosmetic products and open a hairdresser's salon for her daughter.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish for processing and reselling.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margret appreciates the previous loan that helped her expand her business.

She has operated a kiosk retail shop business for the past one year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of creditors taking too long to repay loans. 

With the loan, she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour to stock and sell

loans.name: Matta

texts.en: Matta is a 38-year-old farmer from Barangwaje.  As a Babban Gona member, Matta is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Matta can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Matta can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Yakubu, Emnanuel, and  Deborah. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Janeth Mireya

texts.es:
