This is their ninth group loan with the  Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, seeking to meet their customers' needs.

Mrs. BINTOU, who is sitting in the second position from left to right in the photo of this Askia group of women, sells soft drinks (coca-cola, pineapple juice, tonic water). She intends to use her loan to buy four cases of soft drinks at the main market  for retail sales in Sanoubougou I, where she is in high demand by customers for the quality of her products, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

She expects average monthly profits of 47,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest, and the rest to be put into savings.

loans.use: buy soft drinks (coca-cola, pineapple juice, tonic water)

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en:
Mahammad is 32 years old. He is married and has two daughters. His wife is a housekeeper. Mahammad ’s family is IDP (Internally Displaced Persons) and they have lived in an IDP settlement for a long time. 

Mahammad earns money by growing fruits and vegetables, and selling them at the local bazaar. He has nine years of experience in this area.  The monthly income is 230 AZN.

There is high demand for fruits and vegetables.  Every day people use them in preparing different kinds of fruit juice, jam and vegetable salads. People buy from private gardens because food there is cheaper than in the markets.
 
Mahammad wants to make his family’s life better, and he especially wants to provide for his daughters' future. He applied for 700 AZN loan in order to buy more fertilizers and fruit tree seeds to increase his income.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and fruit tree seeds

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en: Warlito learned about Paglaum MPC and the financial assistance it extends. As a farmer in Plaridel, he tried his luck and borrowed a loan for his corn production. After several months, he was able to return his borrowed capital. To this day, he feels he owes his good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted him with the money he used for his business. Recently, he took a loan to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer for the next cropping season. Warlito wishes to sustain his business and be able to supply corn in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry is 36 years old and lives in Antagan. He is asking for a loan so that he can obtain a water pump to irrigate and expand his crops.

Farming can be a big business for many rural farmers in Isabela. He grows rice seeds on his small farm to sell in town.  This season he is also planning on growing corn.

Because it is the dry season in Isabela, water needs to be applied to the crops regularly. A water pump would significantly reduce Jerry’s need for labour and allow him to further expand his gardens.

loans.use: to buy a water pump for his farming business

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is 44 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Norma has borrowed and paid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal and rice.

Norma aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Erwina

texts.en:
Erwina is 41 years old and married with five children, four of whom are in school.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like soap, shampoo, eggs, milk, etc.

Erwina has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and earns additional income from fishing.

She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to puchase more stock to sell like soap, shampoo, eggs and milk

loans.name: Mjeni

texts.en:
Mjeni is a married woman with five children, three of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For the past eight years, Mjeni has operated a mat weaving business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of expanding and also establishing a poultry business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting, she wants to purchase paints and sewing materials. Mjeni decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase paints and sewing materials.

loans.name: Mary Cris

texts.en: Mary Cris is 27 years old, married and has two children. In order to have a source of income and help her husband in a simple way, Mary Cris engaged herself in a retail business. Mary Cris sells bread, eggs, canned goods, and condiments in their village. She also sells different menu items for meals. Mary Cris doesn’t want to close her retailing business because she needs additional capital to sell her cooked menu. For this reason, Mary Cris is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy soft drinks, bread, noodles and many more grocery items. She hopes that both of her businesses will continue to operate and generate income as well.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, bread, noodles and many more grocery items

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is a married woman with eight children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Estrella is 44 years old and three of her children are currently in school.

Estrella has a fruit vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fruits to sell in her fruit stand.

Estrella has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fruits to sell in her fruit stand

loans.name: Jumelle Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe JUMELLE  sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles  à  SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers populaires dans la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame  DJENEBA  assise à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes JUMELLE, fait la vente  des  jus d’orange, eau en sachet.
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 1 sac de 50 kg du sucre, 100 kg de gingembre, des quantités important d’eau en sachet de 50fcfa  au grand marché d’où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits pour la revendre en détail  à  SANOUBOUGOU I à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 48 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The five members of the Jumelle group are married women who on average are 41 years old with five children. Most of them live in traditional families in Sanoubougou I, one of the populous neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their ninth group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, seeking to meet their customers' needs.

Mrs. Djeneba, who is sitting in the second position from left to right in the photo of this Jumelle group of women, sells pouches of orange juice and water. She intends to use her loan to buy one 50-kilo bag of sugar, 100 kilos of ginger, and large quantities of water in pouches, at the main market.

Retail sales are conducted in Sanoubougou I, where she is in high demand by customers for the quality of her products, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

She expects average monthly profits of 48,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest, and the rest to be put into savings.

loans.use: buy ingredients to prepare pouches of fruit juices and mineral water

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Retailing helps Remedios insure her family survives. She sells fish around the neighborhood. She found the business easy and simple because all she has to do is take time to weigh fish for the buyers. Remedios plans to expand her food business. She applied for a loan from PMPC for the capital she needs. She wants to purchase more kilos of fish to sell. She smiles at the fact that she will see all her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase more kilos of fish to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 41 years old and married with five children. With three of her children currently in school, she works very hard to provide for them.

Evelyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Evelyn has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as rice, soy sauce, noodles, juice, cooking oil, snack foods, etc. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
An $800 loan is offered to Helena to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2007 with her own working capital of $200. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store like a refrigerator, water, beer, Fanta, noodles and slippers. She is generating a good income from selling.

She has been thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in doing business. She is living in a town with her family.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator, water, beer, Fanta, noodles and slippers

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Monsieur DAOUDA est né vers 1961 à NEBADOUGOU, marié, père de 10 enfants, il réside chez lui-même avec ses épouses dans une famille traditionnelle à NEBADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ième région administrative de la république du MALI.
Il collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien son activité agricole pendant l’hivernage. 
Il est à son deuxième prêt de production de maïs avec l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le prêt précédant a été correctement remboursé.  
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs , ce prêt lui permettra de faire l’achat de 24 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 30 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 3 hectares.
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau de village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 450 000 francs CFA par campagne. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Daouda was born around 1961 in Nebadougou. He is the married father of ten children, and lives with his wives in his own traditional family home in Nebadougou, a village in the Danderesso municipality, which is part of the Sikasso Circle, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

He collaborates with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out his farming activities during the rainy season.

This is his second maize production loan with the institution, and the prior loan has been correctly repaid.

The featured crop is maize, and this loan will enable him to buy 24 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 30 containers of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for plowing to maintain 3 hectares (about 7.4 acres).

The crop is sold after harvest at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

He expects to achieve average profits of 450,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable him to pay off his loan and its interest, and contribute towards daily family expenditures.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and herbicide, and pay for plowing

loans.name: Gasenyi Group

texts.fr:
Mélanie  fait partie du groupe  Gasenyi et  habite à  Gitega. Elle a 43 ans et est mariée à Simon, un maçon. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 5 à 20 ans,dont 3 étudient. 

Elle fait le commerce du riz,de manioc,...dans son restaurant  depuis  7 ans. 

C’est son premier   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de riz, de manioc,… à revendre cuits dans son restaurant, pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une parcelle, et voir se enfants étudient.
texts.en:
Melanie is part of the Gasenyi group, and lives in Gitega. She is 43 years old and is married to Simon, a mason. Together they have five children from 5 to 20 years of age, of whom three attend school. 

She has been selling rice, cassava, ... in her restaurant for the past seven years.

This is her first credit loan with Turame. With the Kiva loan, she will increase her working capital and buy large quantities of rice, cassava, ... to sell once cooked in her restaurant, to earn more. 

In coming years she would like to buy a plot of land and ensure her children's education.

loans.use: increase her working capital and buy large quantities of rice, cassava,..., for sale once cooked in her restaurant, to earn more.

loans.name: Benkaditon Group

texts.fr:
Les 8 membres du groupe BENKADITON sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 51 ans et ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à FINKOLO ZANZO un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur DRISSA débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme BENKADITON . 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  8 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 10 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  1 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  160 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Benkaditon group are married men who on average are 51 years old with eight children, and live for the most part in Finkolo Zanzo, a village in the Danderesso municipality, which is part of the Sikasso Circle, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their farming activities during the rainy season.

This is their second maize production loan with the institution, and the prior loan has been correctly repaid.

The selected crop is maize featuring Mr. Drissa, who is standing in the first position from right to left in the picture of this Benkaditon group of men. He intends to use this loan to buy eight 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 10 containers of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for plowing to maintain one hectare (about 2.4 acres).

The crop is sold after harvest at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

He expects to achieve average profits of 160,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable him to pay off his loan and its interest, and also to contribute towards daily family expenditures.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and herbicide, and pay for plowing

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children and all of them go to school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past year, she has operated a mat weaving business to earn a living and support her family. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sewing materials and thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sewing materials and thread for her business

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe DANAYA sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 44 ans, et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles  à  OUAYERMA I  un des quartiers populaires dans la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur quatorzième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame  AMINATA  assise à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes DANAYA, fait la vente du pain.
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt quantités importantes de pain, elle s’approvisionne dans une boulangerie de son quartier d’où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits pour la revendre en détail  de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 36 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Danaya group are married women who on average are 44 years old with four children. Most of them live in traditional families in Ouayerma I, one of the populous neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

This is their fourteenth group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, seeking to meet their customers' needs.

Mrs. Aminata, who is sitting in the first position from left to right in the photo of this Danaya group of women, sells bread.

She intends to use her loan to buy large quantities of bread from a bakery in her neighborhood, where she is in high demand by customers for the quality of her products. She then retails the bread as an itinerant vendor, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

She expects average monthly profits of 36,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest, and the rest to be put into savings.

loans.use: buy bread

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.en: Lorenza is 63 years old, married and lives in Plaridel. In order to earn a living she raises pigs in her own backyard. Paglaum has supported the needed capital to purchase her original piglets and feed. Now, she requests a loan to buy additional feed. She really hopes and prays that her business would grow and benefit her family, in addition to the income of her husband. Someday, she wants to build a concrete pig cage to more easily keep sanitary conditions.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of feeds

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida is 38 years old and married with four children.

Loida works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested an 11,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Loida has borrowed and paid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for one year and also earns additional income from food vending.

Loida aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en:
Genevieve is single and has a videoke machine rental business in the Philippines.

Genevieve requested a 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to pay electric bills and buy spare parts for the maintenance of her business.

Genevieve has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Genevieve would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to pay electric bills and buy spare parts for the maintenance of her business

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 36 years old and married with six children.

Jacqueline works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 11,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

Jacqueline has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Jacqueline aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Nzalambi

texts.en:
Nzalambi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Renie

texts.en: Renie is 49 years old, single, and involved in a farming business to help his parents. Renie is a very responsible brother and son. He always seeks the needs of his brother and sister and even the daily needs of his parents. He is asking a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to buy fertilizer and seeds for his farming business. With this loan, Renie is well on his way to achieving his dream.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds for his farming business.

loans.name: Rocelyn

texts.en:
Rocelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a restaurant business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to purchase additional vegetables, meat, canned goods, spices, etc. for her restaurant business.

Rocelyn has been in this business for 5 years. Rocelyn earns more income from buying and selling fruits and pre-paid mobile load.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables, meat, canned goods, spices, etc.

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah is a 32-year-old married man with three children. Abdullah lives with his children in their own house in Dhamar. His oldest child is 13 years old and the youngest one is 4 years old. He has a university education, and now he is an employee. His house lacks of many home appliances, and most of them are very old. Unfortunately, Abdullah doesn't have enough money to purchase new home appliances and to furnish his house. For this reason, Abdullah is requesting a loan of 120,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB in order to purchase home appliances such as a new refrigerator for the house. 

Abdullah looks forward to improving the living standards of his family. He hopes to make a secure future for his children through sending them to private universities.

loans.use: to purchase home appliances such as a new refrigerator for the house.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is 51 years old and widowed.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling dried fish. Rosalie is borrowing 18,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy fishing materials like net, bamboo, gasoline, etc for her business for her fishing business.

Rosalie has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like net, bamboo, gasoline, etc., for her business

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe SOUTOURA sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles  à  SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers populaires dans la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur quatorzième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame  DIARA  assise à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes SOUTOURA, fait la vente  des oignons.
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 4 paniers de 50 kg d’oignon au grand marché d’où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits pour la revendre en détail  à  SANOUBOUGOU I à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the Soutoura group are married women who on average are 39 years old with five children. Most of them live in traditional families in Sanabougou I, one of the populous neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their fourteenth group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, seeking to meet their customers' needs.

Mrs. Diara, who is sitting in the second position from right to left in the photo of this Soutoura group of women, sells onions.

She intends to use her loan to buy four 50-kilo baskets of onions from the main market. She then retails them in Sanabougou I, where she is in high demand by customers for the quality of her products, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit.

She expects average monthly profits of 25,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest, and the rest to be put into her savings.

loans.use: buy onions

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional stocks of linen, tailoring chalk, etc. for her tailoring business.

Evangeline has been in this business for 7 years. Evangeline earns more income from food vending.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of linen, tailoring chalk, etc. for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase fish to sell for her dried fish making business.

Angelita has been in this business for three years. Angelita earns more income from raising chickens.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Mary Llanie Grace

texts.en:
Mary Llanie Grace is 30 years old and married. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Mary Llanie Grace has borrowed and repaid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from food vending and a buy-and-sell ready to wear business.

She aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc. at her general store.

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en: Felicitas works hard to support her family. She is widowed and has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients such as fish, vegetables, meat, spices, etc. for her business. Felicitas has been in this business for 30 years now. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as fish, vegetables, meat, spices, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Salima is a married woman. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a cereals shop business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Salima dreams of establishing a wholesale cereals shop business in the future. With the loan that she is requesting of KES 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize  flour, and beans for her food vending business.

loans.name: Djekafo 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 6 membres du groupe DJEKAFO 1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 55 ans et ont en moyenne 10 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à NATIEN un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts anterieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur  KALIFA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme  DJEKAFO 1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  10 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 15 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  1,5 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  240 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 6 members of the Djekafo 1 group are married men who on average are 55 years old with ten children, living for the most part in traditional families in Natien, a village in the Sikasso Circle, the third administrative region of Mali.

They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in carrying out their agricultural activities during the rainy season. 

They are on their second maize production loan with the institution, and the previous loan has been correctly repaid. 

The selected crop is maize featuring Mr. Kalifa, who is standing in the first position from left to right in the photo of this Djekafo 1 group of men.
 
With his loan, he intends to buy ten 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 15 containers of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for plowing to maintain 1.5 hectares (about 3.7 acres). 

The crop is sold after the harvest at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele of men and women, for cash and on credit. 

He expects to achieve average profits of 240,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable him to pay off the loan and its interest, and also to contribute towards the family's daily expenditures.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and herbicide, and pay for plowing

loans.name: Djekafo 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 membres du groupe DJEKAFO 2 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 54 ans et ont en moyenne 11 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à NATIEN un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur AMIDOU débout au milieu sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme  DJEKAFO 2. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  10 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 15 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  1,5 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  240 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Djekafo 2 group are married men who on average are 54 years old with eleven children, living for the most part in traditional families in Natien, a village in the Sikasso Circle, the third administrative region of Mali.

They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their agricultural activities during the rainy season.

They are on their second maize production loan with the institution, and the previous loan has been correctly repaid.

The selected crop is maize featuring Mr. Amidou, who is standing in the middle of the photo of this Djekafo 2 group of men.

With his loan, he intends to buy ten 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 15 containers of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for plowing to maintain 1.5 hectares (about 3.7 acres).

The crop is sold after the harvest at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele of men and women, for cash and on credit.

He expects to achieve average profits of 240,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable him to pay off the loan and its interest, and also to contribute towards the family's daily expenditures.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and herbicide, and pay for plowing

loans.name: Fadenkene Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe FADENKENE sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans, et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles  au QUARTIER 1 un quartier populaire dans la ville de LOULOUNI dans le cercle de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur vingtième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame KAMISSA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes FADENKENE, fait la  restauration.
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 3 sacs 50 kg de riz, des quantités importantes de condiment pour la bonne restauration d’où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses plats alimentaires. Sa restauration se fait au marché à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the Fandenkene group are married women who on average are 46 years old with four children, living for the most part in traditional families in Quartier 1, a populous neighborhood in the city of Loulouni, which is part of the Sikasso Circle, the third administrative region of Mali.

They are on their twentieth group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, seeking to satisfy  their customers' needs.

Mrs. Kamissa, who is standing in the first position from left to right in the photo of this Fandenkene group of women, sells food preparations.

She intends to use her loan to buy three 50-kilo bags of rice and large quantities of condiments to prepare good meals for which she is in high demand by her customers, due to the quality of her food preparations.

Her food preparations are sold at the market to a clientele of men and women, for cash and on credit.

She expects to achieve average monthly profits of 30,000 CFA francs, part of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interest, and the remainder to be put into savings.

loans.use: buy rice and condiments

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en: Aurea lives in Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is married and manages an electronic shop together with her husband, who has been the repairman for 15 years already. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional bronze rods, flux, copper and other accessories and materials for the repair shop business. She has been a member of PMPC for eight years. In the future, she hopes to expand their radiator repair shop business.

loans.use: To purchase additional bronze rods, flux, copper and other accessories and materials for her electronics repairing business.

loans.name: Chiru

texts.en:
Chiru operates a grocery stall; she sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbours. She faces the challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale business in the future and she appreciates the support of her previous loan, which helped her in her business.


With the loan of KES 50,000 she would like to buy a variety of vegetables, onions, tomatoes and fruits for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy variety of vegetables, onions, tomatoes and fruits to sell.

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en:
Leslie is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from clothing sales.  Leslie is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF in order to buy ingredients for her food business.

Leslie has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is a widowed woman with four children, two who are currently in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. She is 45 years old. 

Milagros has a direct-selling Avon products business in the Philippines. Milagros requested a PHP15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more products from Avon to sell to her customers.

Milagros has been in this business for six years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more products from Avon to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana has requested a loan of US $800 to improve her business. She runs a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as sugar, oils, cigarettes, candles, body lotion and noodles.  She opened her kiosk in 2007 with her own working capital of US $1000.  She is a hard working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, oils, cigarettes, candles, body lotion and noodles.

loans.name: Tuvyurane Group

texts.fr:
Innocent  fait partie du groupe  Tuvyurane et  habite à  Cibitoke. Il  a 43 ans et est marié  à  Herda, une cultivatrice. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 1  à 13  ans,dont 3 étudient. 

Il fait le commerce de boutique(riz, haricot,limonade,...) depuis  7 ans. 

Il est à son deuxième son crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il va  augmenter son capital et acheter  100kilos de  riz, 50 kilos de haricot  à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il  voudrait  acheter une moto pour son déplacement, et voir se enfants étudient.
texts.en:
Innocent is a member of the Tuvyurane group and lives in Cibitoke. He is 43 years old and is married to Herda, a farmer. Together they have five children, who age from one to 13 years old. Three of the children go to school.

Innocent has been selling items (rice, beans, lemonade, etc.) in a shop for seven years. He is on his second loan with Turame. With this Kiva-financed loan, he is going to increase his capital to buy 100 kilograms of rice and 50 kilograms of beans, which he will resell to earn more.

In the coming years, he would like to buy a moped and see his children go to school.

loans.use: to buy 100 kilograms of rice and 50 kilograms of beans

loans.name: Sevil

texts.en:
Sevil is 64 years old, married, and the mother of four children. Her husband is a teacher at school, but his earnings from this job are not enough. The main source of income for family is farming. Sevil raises and sells seasonal vegetables such as pumpkin, cucumber, potatoes, and so on. She has been raising them and selling at the local bazaar for 24 years and has good experience in this area. Her monthly income is 200 AZN. 

Vegetables are in high demand in Azerbaijan because people like to use them for fresh salads and delicious national dishes. They attend local groceries and buy there fresh and tasty vegetables. They know that vegetables raised in private gardens are always fresh and without pesticides. Sevil needs money to cover family’s demands. She applied for 1,200 AZN in order to supply quality fertilizers and increase harvest and income.

loans.use: to supply quality fertilizers and increase harvest and income.

loans.name: Jegnogonton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEGNOGONTON 1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 53 ans et ont en moyenne 10 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à DANDERESSO une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur ABOU débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme JEGNOGONTON 1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  2 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  320 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Jegnogonton 1 group are married men who, on average, are 53 years old and have 10 children. They mostly live in traditional families in Danderesso, a commune in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Abou, who is standing first from the right in the photo, grows corn. With this loan, he plans to buy 16 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 20 drums of different quality herbicides. He will also pay the cost of plowing two hectares of land. 

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit. 

Abou hopes to earn an average profit of 320,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest and to help take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to pay the cost of plowing

loans.name: Gnanan 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe GNANAN 1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47 ans et ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à NEBADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur quatrième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur KLEZIE débout à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme  GNANAN 1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 8 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 10 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  1 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  160 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Gnanan 1 group are married men who, on average, are 47 years old and have eight children. They mostly life in traditional families in Nebadougou, a village in Danderesso, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. The are on their fourth loan, and their previous loans have been repaid correctly.

Klezie, who is standing second from the right in the photo, grows corn. With his loan, he plans to buy eight 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 10 drums of different quality herbicides. He will also pay the cost to plow one hectare of land. 

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Klezi hopes to earn an average profit of 160,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest and to help take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay the cost of plowing

loans.name: Teodoro

texts.en: Teodoro is a farmer from Antagan. He stated that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Teodoro to join ASKI. Now, as a member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  However, Teodoro is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”.

loans.use: To buy pesticide, seeds and fertilizer for his farm business

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en: Bonifacia is driven by a passion for selling. At the age of 62, she runs a store that primarily supports her family. She is married and from Plaridel. Everyday she never gets tired of tending to her store. She is a full fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. She religiously repaid her obligations without records of default. Now, she borrowed another loan to pay for inventories of sugar, milk, oil, and noodles to sell. Having enough inventories would mean income opportunities. In the future, she dreams of sustaining her store to provide for her family continuously.

loans.use: to pay for inventories of sugar, milk, oil, noodles to sell.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic, aged 34, is a married woman with four children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Marivic has had a tricycle transportation business in the Philippines for the past eight years. 

She has now requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF in order to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

In the future, Marivic would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is 60 years old and widowed with seven children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 26,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of items such as soap, shampoo, eggs, canned goods, etc. to sell. 

Elsa has borrowed and repaid 23 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal. Elsa aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of items such as soap, shampoo, eggs, canned goods, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Nzadze

texts.en: Nzadze has operated a food kiosk business selling food stuff of maize flour and cooking fat to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned the high cost of seasonality as her major challenge. Nzadze dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil for her food stall business.

loans.name: Jegnogonton 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEGNOGONTON 2 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans et ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à DANDERESSO une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur BAKARY assis à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme JEGNOGONTON 2. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  2 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  320 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Jegnogonton 2 group are married men who, on average, are 48 years old and have eight children. They mostly live in traditional families in Danderesso, a commune in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have been repaid correctly.

Bakary, who is seated second from the left in the photo, grows corn. With this loan, he plans to buy 16 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 20 drums of different quality herbicide. He will also pay the cost of plowing two hectares of land.

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Bakary hopes to earn an average profit of 320,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest and to take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to pay the cost of plowing

loans.name: Babyncia

texts.en:
Babyncia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP10,000 through NWTF to buy additional bundles of fishing nets for her business. Babyncia has been in this business for three years. She earns more income from buying and selling dried fish.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net bundles.

loans.name: Mjeni

texts.en:
Mjeni is a married woman who lives with her husband and eight children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past 17 years, Mjeni has operated a charcoal-selling business. She sells from her home to neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation. Mjeni dreams of expanding her business to become a wholesale supplier of firewood in the village. 

With the Kshs 50,000 loan, Mjeni wants to purchase bundles of charcoal to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Daudi

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Daudi, a 37-year-old small scale farmer who hails from the Nyamira area of Kenya. He is a family man and married with five children who he always refers to as “his heartbeat." Daudi is involved in the dairy business, which is an important source of subsidiary income to small, marginal farmers and agricultural laborers in rural Kenya. Juhudi Kilimo partnered with Kiva to provide financial and technical support to farmers such as Daudi who have been practicing mixed farming for the past 10 years. Daudi passionately loves dairy farming and has nicknamed one of his cows “nyamutuki." Although he makes profits from dairy farming he has the challenge of not having a proper dairy unit, which is why he is kindly requesting a loan to construct a modern dairy unit.

Dairy cows require proper care so that they can produce higher volumes of milk and they also require a proper place for them to rest so that they are not affected by bad weather conditions. Through the loan Daudi will be able to improve his milk production because he will have a good place to milk his cows and reduce the chance of sickness. Hence, he will save more money that would have been spent on buying animal medicine. This loan will assist David to collect cow dung that will be used to improve vegetable production on his farm, and he can also use the cow dung to make his hut look beautiful.

Daudi has a good culture of saving. He projects that through accumulated profits he will be able to save and buy more quality dairy cows and also be able to pay back the loan. 

Daudi waits for your kindness.

loans.use: to construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Jegnogonton 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe JEGNOGONTON 3 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans et ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à DANDERESSO une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur LASSINA NAGOLE  debout à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme JEGNOGONTON 3. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  2 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  320 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Jegnogonton 3 group are married men who, on average, are 50 years old and have eight children. They mostly live in traditional families in Danderesso, a commune in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have been repaid correctly.

Lassina Nagole, who is standing second from the right in the photo, grows corn. With his loan, he plans to buy 16 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 20 drums of different quality herbicide. He will also pay the cost of plowing two hectares of land.

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Lassina Nagole hopes to earn an average profit of 320,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest and to take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay the cost of plowing

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Wonderful Kiva lenders! Introducing you to Peter, a 34-year-old honest, hard-working and ever-smiling father of two adorable children. He hails from  Nyamira in Kenya, a banana-growing area where the staple food is “matoke”, a mouthwatering delicacy prepared from bananas. Peter has been involved in farming for the past 14 years and he owns dairy cows that produce milk for sale. Besides his dairy cows, he also keeps poultry and when you visit his farm you will witness tea growing as well as a variety of vegetables.
.
Peter has a passion for dairy farming and has even nicknamed one of his cows “Nyaera” (from a person's name) but all is not well for this humble man. He is facing the challenge of the lack of a proper dairy unit which is why he is seeking funds to construct a proper dairy unit. With your loan, he will be able to better manage his dairy farm and create more value. A better dairy unit will assist Peter to save more money because his cows will never be sick and this will also boost his dairy's milk production. 

Through building a dairy unit with the loan, Peter will be able to collect the cows' by-products, namely, cow dung and urine which can be sold or better yet used on his farm. With a dairy unit, he will be able to better feed his animals and collect by-products such as dung to generate biogas fuel, make organic fertilizer and plaster his hut. The money that he will earn from the dairy unit will be reinvested back into the business to create growth.

Peter is a very ambitious man and he projects that through the loan he will have higher quality dairy cows and be able to permanently change his living conditions and secure his children's future.

loans.use: To build a dairy unit

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa is 62 years old and has 10 children. She is widowed and has two children who are still in school. Tomasa is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines which she has been doing for the past 30 years,  

Tomasa has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. She has now requested a PHP 35,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Tomasa would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Nelmy Lizeth

texts.es: Nelmy, tiene 43 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 3 hijos, reside con su familia en el municipio de Olanchito, Yoro. Hace 4 años decidió por establecer su propia fuente de ingresos y comenzó con una pulpería donde vende granos básicos como arroz, frijoles, maíz, carnes, manteca, azúcar, pastas, huevos, pan,refrescos, y golosinas. Para aumentar el inventario y ventas ha solicitado otro préstamo que es el cuarto ciclo y es por 15,000 lempiras, con el cual va comprar granos básicos, carnes, refrescos y golosinas. Su objetivo es hacer crecer el negocio y poderles dar mejor educación a su familia.
texts.en: Nelmy is 43 years old and is married with 3 children. She lives with her family in the Olanchito municipality in Yoro. 4 years ago she decided to establish her own source of income by opening a general store where she sells staple goods like rice, beans, corn, meat, butter, sugar, pasta, eggs, bread, soft drinks and candy. To improve her stock and sales she has requested another loan which is her fourth loan cycle and is for 15, 000 lempiras, which she will use to buy basic grains, meat, drinks and candy. Her objective is to expand her business and be able to give her family a better education.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, meat, soft drinks and candy.

loans.name: Jiguiseme Group

texts.fr:
Les 9 membres du groupe JIGUISEME sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et ont en moyenne 7 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des familles traditionnelles à FOH un village dans la commune de KOUROUMA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur septième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts anterieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur KLEZANGA débout à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme JIGUISEME. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter  8 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 10 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  1 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  160 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The nine members of the Jiguiseme group are married men who, on average, are 45 years old and have seven children. They mostly live in traditional families in Foh, a village in Kourouma, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their seventh loan, and their previous loans have been repaid correctly.

Klezanga, who is standing second from the right in the photo, grows corn. With his loan, he plans to buy eight 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 10 drums of different quality herbicide. He will also pay the cost of plowing one hectare of land. 

After the harvest, crops are sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Klezanga hopes to earn an average profit of 160,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest and to take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay the cost of plowing

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is married with six children. She earns a living through buying and selling scrap materials with this business primarily supporting her family. Susan believed there was money in trash and, true enough, it gives her a promising income of PHP 8,000 a month. 

Now, Susan plans to expand her business by opening another location. She wants to purchase scrap materials to sell and so she has approached PMPC for the capital that she needs. Susan hopes to repay all her obligations to PMPC without default.

loans.use: to purchase scrap materials to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Hoima, Uganda and is divorced with three children. She runs a retail shop selling mainly soap, cooking oil ,sugar and detergent. Sarah earns supplementary income from the production of crops, in particular, maize. 

Sarah wishes to expand her business although inadequate capital is still a setback. She will use the money from the loan to buy sugar, soap and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, soap and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie, aged 43, is married with four children who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Analie has had a rice retailing business in the Philippines for the past 14 years. 

Analie has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Coumba's Group

texts.fr:
Le banc villageois d’APRESS est  Créé en   Juin 2009 le  jour de  son inauguration. Les femmes qui le composent sont très engagées dans le développement de leur organisation, elles viennent d’entamer leur dixième cycle. Toutes issues du même quartier, Elles ont un esprit d’entre aide et de solidaire très remarquable.  Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame  Coumba (assise à extrême droite avec une main levée) est l’emprunteuse vedette  du groupe. Elle est âgée de 38ans, est mariée et mère de 06 enfants dont 03 filles et 03 garçons. Elle tient une table dans son quartier où elle vend des légumes frais. Elle achète le plus souvent sa marchandise au marché international de la sous région par sac ou bassine selon la nature de produits. La revente se fait par tas ou à l’unité selon les désires du client. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans ce domaine.  

Avec ce prêt elle va acheter des aubergines pour 10 000 Fr CFA la bassine, des condiments (piment, poivre, ail, poivron et autres) pour la revente.

Les bénéfices tirés de ses activités lui permettront d’augmenter son épargne, une partie sera utilisée dans la scolarisation des enfants.
texts.en:
The banc villageois Apress was created in June 2009, on the day of its inauguration. The women who make up this banc villageois are very engaged in the development of their organization. They have just begun their tenth cycle. These women all come from the same area and share a spirit of mutual support and solidarity that is very strong. The women all work primarily in small-scale commerce.

Coumba (who is seated on the far right of the photo with her hand raised) is the featured borrower of this group. She is 38 years old, married, and a mother of six children, of whom three are girls and three are boys. 

Coumba has a stall in her neighborhood where she sells fresh vegetables. She procures her goods according to the season mostly from the international market in her region. She resells these goods in bulk or by piece, according to the customer. She does well with this work.

With this loan, she is going to buy eggplants at 10,000 francs CFA per tub and condiments (chillies, pepper, garlic, peppers, and others) to resell. 

Earnings from this business will allow her to increase her savings and pay for her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy eggplants and condiments (chillies, pepper, garlic, peppers, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice appreciates her previous Kiva loan which improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

For the past four years, she has operated a retail kiosk business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, rice and cooking oil. She cites seasonality as her major challenge in the business. 

Alice is requesting a loan of Kshs 20,000 to boost her kiosk by purchasing wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves and cooking oil. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Asteria Candida

texts.es: Doña Asteria, tiene 76 años de edad, es viuda, reside con un nieto en una aldea del municipio de Olanchito, Yoro. A ella siempre de ha gustado el trabajo y tener su propio negocio, lleva 9 años de vender productos de abarrotería como refrescos, harina, azúcar, manteca, arroz, frijoles, carnes y otros. Ha invertido varios prestamos para mantener su negocio activo, el actual es el noveno ciclo y es por 4,000 lempiras con el cual  va surtir de refrescos, carnes, arroz, azúcar, harina, pan, huevos, manteca, y otros para vender y seguir obteniendo ganancias.. Su plan es seguir manteniendo surtido para generar mas ingresos ya que su sueño es llegar a tener un minisúper y sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en: Doña Asteria is 76 years old, widowed, and lives with her grandson in a village in the municipality of Olanchito, Yoro. She has always enjoyed working and owning her own business. She has spent 9 years selling groceries like refreshments, flour, sugar, lard, rice, beans, meats, amongst others. She has invested numerous loans into keeping her business running. The current loan is the ninth cycle and is for 4,000 lempiras, with which she will purchase a selection of refreshments, meats, rice, sugar, flour, bread, eggs, lard, and other goods to sell and continue making profits. Her plan is to maintain a good selection to generate more income as her dream is to own a mini supermarket and to provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a selection of refreshments, meats, rice, sugar, flour, bread, eggs, lard, and other goods to sell.

loans.name: Erminda Eduviges

texts.es: Doña Erminda, tiene 41 años de edad, vive en unión libre con su esposo con quien tiene 3 hijos, reside en el municipio del Progreso, Yoro. Siempre se ha dedicado al negocio de comidas, tiene un puesto de venta a orilla de carretera donde vende baleadas, desayunos y almuerzos. este negocio lo tiene desde hace 10 años de donde a podido sacar adelante a su familia. Ha solicitado seis ciclos de préstamo con el actual que es por 10,000 lempiras para comprar insumos como harina, frijoles, lácteos, carnes, arroz, condimentos, vegetales etc.para elaborar comidas y vender. mediante la inversión de prestamos ha podido mantener el negocio y su meta es lograr que sus hijos se gradúen y también ampliar mas el local del negocio.
texts.en: Erminda is 41 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their 3 children in the municipality of Progreso, Yoro. She has always made a living in the food industry. She has a stall on the side of the road where she sells filled tortillas, breakfast and lunch. She has had this business for 10 years, allowing her to provide for her family. She has requested six loan cycles, the current one being for 10,000 lempiras to buy ingredients such as flour, beans, dairy products, meat, rice, condiments, vegetables etc. to make the meals she sells. Thanks to the loan investments she has been able to keep her business afloat and her goal is to see her children graduate and expand her business premises.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as flour, beans, dairy products, meat, rice, condiments, vegetables etc. to make the meals she sells.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr:
Madame Mariama est membre du groupement depuis sa création. C’est l’une des femmes les plus dynamiques malgré son âge avancé 64 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 09 enfants dont 03 filles et 06 garçons dont elle prend exclusivement en charge vu que son mari âgé est atteint de cécité. Elle est vendeuse de jus naturel fait à base de fruits locaux à la gare routière communale. Elle fait cette activité depuis plus de 20 ans et la maîtrise à merveille.

Avec ce nouveau prêt elle désire acquérir un nouveau frigo pour une valeur de 400 000 Fr CF et le reste du prêt servira d’acheter du pain de singe, du bissap, du gingembre, du sucre et divers ingrédients pour la préparation des jus.

Avec les bénéfices, elle prend en charge les besoins de sa famille sur tous les plans sanitaire, habillement, nourriture, scolaire et autres.
texts.en: Ms. Mariama has been a member of the group since its creation. She is one of the most dynamic women despite her advanced age of 64.  She is married and mother of nine children. Because her husband is blind, she alone takes care of the three girls and six boys.  She sells natural juice made from local fruit at the bus station.  She has been in this business for over 20 years and excels at it.  With this new loan, she wants to buy a new refrigerator that costs 400,000 FCF and the remaining funds will be used to buy bread, hibiscus, ginger, sugar, and various other ingredients for making juice.  With the profits, she will take care of all of her family's needs, including healthcare, clothing, food, school fees, etc.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator, bread, hibiscus, ginger, sugar, and other ingredients for juice-making.

loans.name: Segundo Justiniano

texts.es:
Segundo es un hombre trabajador, tiene 49 años de edad, es viudo y vive en San Martin junto a su familia,
Tiene dos maravillosos hijos quienes son su mayor motivación en la vida para salir adelante y por quienes siempre ha luchado para poder brindarles un futuro mejor. Lamentablemente hace varios años sufrió la pérdida de su esposa, pero a pesar del dolor tuvo que superarlo rápido para poder dar fuerza a sus hijos.
Segundo ha salido adelante con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación. Actualmente se dedica a la agricultura, tiene cultivos de cacao, plátano y maíz y le va muy bien porque es muy trabajador, responsable y tiene mucha experiencia en estos cultivos. Es considerado un líder en la zona porque organiza reuniones con sus vecinos para poder brindar capacitaciones y así sus compañeros también puedan superarse.
Segundo está agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado ampliará sus cultivos de caco y plátano y de esta manera podrá tener mayores ganancias. 
Con esto Segundo seguirá esforzándose para más adelante seguir ampliando sus terrenos y poder sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en:
Segundo is a hard working man. He is 49 years old. He is a widower and lives in San Martin with his family.

He has two wonderful children who are his biggest motivation to succeed and for whom he has always fought in order to provide them with a better future. 

Unfortunately, several years ago he suffered the loss of his wife, but despite the pain he had to overcome it rapidly in order to be able to give his children strength.

Segundo has come through with a great deal of hard work and dedication. 

Currently, he works in agriculture. He has cocoa, banana and maize crops and is doing very well because he is very hard working and responsible and has a lot of experience in these crops. He is considered to be a leader in the area, because he holds meetings with his neighbours to provide training. Through this, his colleagues can also improve their lot.

Segundo is grateful to the Kiva lenders, because with the support they have given he will expand his cocoa and banana crops and thus will be able to have higher profits. With this, Segundo will continue to strive to further expand his land and to raise his family.

loans.use: to expand his land (crops)

loans.name: Evelio

texts.es: Don Evelio, tiene 49 años de edad, esta casado, tiene un hijo y reside con su familia en una aldea que pertenece a Gracias, Lempira. Siempre se ha dedicado a la agricultura junto a su familia. Hace 10 años que tiene sus propios cultivos de maíz, frijoles y café. Las cosechas de sus cultivos las vende a intermediarios y mercados de la zona. Para poder mantener en buen estado su finca y mejorar la cosecha e ingresos ha solicitado un segundo préstamo con el cual va comprar abonos para fertilizar los cultivos de café, maíz y frijoles. Tiene como plan adquirir mas terreno para ampliar los cultivos y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en: Don Evelio is 49 years old, married with one son and lives with his family in a village in Gracias, Lempira. He has always worked in agriculture together with his family. For 10 years, he has grown his own corn, bean and coffee crops. He sells his harvests to a go-between and local markets. To keep his property in good condition, improve his harvest and income, he has requested a second loan which he will use to buy manure to fertilise his coffee, corn and bean crops. He plans to acquire more land to expand his crops and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy manure to fertilise his coffee, corn and bean crops.

loans.name: Ousmane's Group

texts.fr:
Ce banc villageois est créé en Décembre 2009 et compte en son sein des femmes animées d’une volonté manifeste à changer les conditions d’existence de leur famille respective. Elles jouissent d’une expérience consolidée dans le programme des bancs villageois vu qu’elles viennent d’entamer leur dixième cycle. Elles vivent toutes dans la même localité et partagent de forts liens de solidarité. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Ousmane (assise à l’extrême droite dans la photo avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette  du groupe, c’est une femme très dynamique et joue un rôle très déterminant dans la progression du banc villageois. Elle est âgée de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 03  enfants (2 Garçons et 1 fille). Elle a une place au marché central à l’entrée de la gare routière où elle vend des fruits et des œufs cuits, elle a une très grande expérience  dans ce domaine.

Avec ce prêt elle désire acheter 50Kg de banane, 02 bassines de mangue à 3 000 Fr CFA et 03 sacs de  pomme de liane communément appelé « madd » tous les 15 jours au moins.
 
Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront d’augmenter son épargne, de mieux assister ses enfants dans la vie en générale et d’achever au fur et à mesure les travaux de finition de sa maison.
texts.en: This "banc villageois" was created in December 2009 and consists of active women who are driven by a clear desire to change the living conditions of their respective families.  They enjoy a consolidated experience in the "banc villageois" program and are on their tenth loan cycle.  They all live in the same area and share strong ties.  Their main activity is small business. Ms. Ousmane (sitting at the far right of the photo with her hand raised) is the representative of this group. She is a very dynamic woman and plays a decisive role in the development of the "banc villageois". She is 46 years old, married, and mother of three children, two boys and one girl.  She has a place in the central market at the entrance of the bus station where she sells fruit and cooked eggs.  She has extensive experience in this domain.  With this loan, she wants to buy 50 kg of bananas, 2 basins of mangoes for 3,000 FCFA, and 3 bags of passionfruit commonly called "madd", at least every 15 days.
